    14yes but poor curve fit binding 
    15Y5.1binding 
    16Y4.5binding4.4 ± 0.09 (2)
    17Y4.3binding 

    Structure–Activity Relationships

    The most potent qualified hits had single-digit micromolar IC50 (pIC50 5.0–6.0) in the ATAD2 TR-FRET assay (Table 3). Selectivity against the BET family bromodomains is desirable to avoid the extensive pharmacology associated with their inhibition, and this was measured using TR-FRET fluoroligand displacement assays in mutant tandem BET bromodomains.(20) Below 50 μM, none of the phenylsulfonamides showed significant binding to BRD4, which we use as a representative of the rest of the BET family (Table 3; full data in Table S2, Supporting Information). ATAD2 SPR dissociation constants were consistent with the ATAD2 TR-FRET IC50s (Table 4).
    The hits contained little variation at the R1 position, with only chloride and methyl substituents represented. The chloride analogues mostly had better potency; for example, chloride 2 is about 10-fold more potent than its direct methyl analogue 12. Variants at the R2 position included simple cyclic and symmetrically disubstituted acyclic amines, with piperidine the most heavily represented. In contrast, a variety of larger chemically distinct substituents were tolerated at the R3 position.
    As the most potent example, we chose 2 for further investigation. Chiral separation generated two undefined stereoisomers, 18 and 19, whose ATAD2 potency was indistinguishable from racemate 2 (Table 5). For the initial investigation of chemistry, we therefore opted to leave the racemic 4-methyl 4-cyclopropyl hydantoin group at R3, as well as the piperidine at R2 unchanged, and varied the R1 position by introducing small modifications.
    The chemistry to access the noncommercial compounds discussed in this article is described in Scheme 1. Synthesis of the inhibitors started from sulfonyl chlorides 24, which in most cases were commercially available (X = Cl, Br, Me, F) or easily accessible by chlorosulfonylation of the para-substituted nitrobenzine (X = ethyl, Cl).(34) The formation of the sulfonamide followed by reduction of the nitro group with Fe(0) gave aniline 25, which could then be coupled with commercially available acid 26 to give compound 23 or with propionyl chloride to give compounds 29, 34, and 35. It was then possible to obtain the trifluoromethyl derivatives 20 and 28 from bromide 23 or 35, respectively, using methyl fluorosulfonyl difluoroacetate.(35) Phenol 30, aniline 31, or nitrile 32 could all be obtained from bromide 35 using either palladium- or copper-catalyzed chemistry.
    The R1 = CF3 derivative (20) was roughly equipotent to the methyl analogue 12 but less active than chloride 2 (Table 5). Increasing the size of the R1 group to methoxy, 21, abolished measurable binding, as did replacing R1 with hydrogen (22), highlighting the tight size restriction of groups at R1. Only the bromide analogue 23 had improved potency over the chloride, by approximately 5-fold, producing the first sub-micromolar lead compound in this series (pIC50 6.5, IC50 300 nM). All of these R1 analogues had minimal BRD4 potency. 23, the most potent ATAD2 compound for which the selectivity window was most measurable, achieved >100-fold selectivity over BRD4 BD1 and 60-fold over BRD4 BD2. Binding to BRD2, BRD3, and BRDT bromodomains was also negligible (Table S2, Supporting Information).
    Table 5. ATAD2 and BRD4 Potencies for Compounds 18–23
    compoundR1stereochemistryATAD2 pIC50BRD4 BD1 pIC50BRD4 BD2 pIC50
    2Clracemic5.9 ± 0.08 (12)<4.3 (4)4.3 (1/4a)
    18Clenantiomer 15.9 ± 0.04 (4)5.0 ± 0.39 (2/3a)4.5 ± 0.06 (2/3a)
    19Clenantiomer 25.9 ± 0.09 (4)<4.3 (3)<4.3 (3)
    12Meracemic4.9 ± 0.22 (5/6a)<4.3 (2)<4.3 (2)
    20CF3racemic5.0 ± 0.08 (8)<4.3 (2)4.6 (1/2a)
    21OMeracemic<4.0 (4)<4.3 (1)<4.3 (1)
    22Hracemic<4.0 (2)<4.3 (4)4.5 (1/4a)
    23Brracemic6.5 ± 0.15 (8)4.3 (1/3a)4.7 ± 0.08 (3)
    a

    Some results below the curve-fitting threshold could not be included in mean and SD. In these cases, the numbers included in the mean/number of times tested are both shown.

    Returning to Table 3, the activity of compounds such as 3, 8, and 16 suggested that the hydantoin R3 substituent may not be critical. We therefore prepared a small number of heavily truncated fragments to assess the baseline activity of the minimal phenylsulfonamide core and simultaneously to test additional small R1 substituents, as shown in Scheme 1. The minimal chloride fragment 27 was significantly less potent than parent 2 but retained some measurable activity (pIC50 ∼ 4.1, Table 6). Fragments could be tested at concentrations up to 1 mM, enabling us to conclude that most chlorine replacements (28–34) resulted in the loss of activity, consistent with the results from the larger scaffold in Table 5. Compound 27 gave partial responses at the concentrations tested (46–55% response at 100 μM), whereas the others showed little response in the 100 μM to 1 mM range on all test occasions. As before, only the bromide (35) was a better R1 group than the chloride (27) by approximately 5-fold. These results also showed that although our initial hits contained active compounds with various R3 substituents, reducing the size of R3 to ethyl resulted in a significant drop in potency (compare 35 to 23, ∼50-fold, and 27 to 2, ∼60-fold), indicating that the hydantoin R3 group does contribute to ATAD2 binding.
    Table 6. ATAD2 Potency for Fragments 27–35
    compoundR1ATAD2 pIC50
    27Cl4.1 (1/4a)
    28CF3<3.0 (8)
    29F<3.0 (10)
    30OH<3.0 (8)
    31NH2<3.0 (8)
    32CN<3.0 (6)
    33OMe<3.0 (4)
    34Et<3.0 (10)
    35Br4.8 ± 0.16 (10)
    a

    Maximum response for 27 was 45–55% at 100–300 μM.

    23 was a validated lead molecule with activity against ATAD2 and selectivity over the BET bromodomains. The SAR indicated that bromide was the optimal R1 group and that R3 groups including the hydantoin contributed significantly to ATAD2 activity. In TR-FRET binding assays against other bromodomains, 23 had a promising selectivity profile with sub-micromolar activity against ATAD2 and ATAD2B, at least 10-fold selectivity activity against CECR2, TAF1 and BRPF3, and little binding to bromodomains such as BPTF, BRD7, BRD9, and CREBBP (Figure 8a). It also showed activity against endogenous ATAD2 in the bromosphere assay (Figure 8b). Further optimization of this series against the bromodomain of ATAD2 and also against CECR2, including screening against a broader bromodomain panel, is described in a second publication.(36) The remainder of this manuscript focuses on understanding the interactions of the core phenylsulfonamide moiety with ATAD2.

    X-ray Structural and Computational Studies

    The common acetyl-lysine binding motifs of bromodomains are well understood and have been extensively reviewed.(15) Acetyl-lysine and most known bromodomain inhibitors form a pair of hydrogen bonds to the W1 water of a water network lying at the base of the pocket and to a conserved asparagine side chain (Asn1064 in ATAD2). However, the conserved parts of the phenylsulfonamide series resembled no previously reported acetyl-lysine mimetic, suggesting the possibility of a novel mode of interaction.
    We therefore tried to obtain X-ray structures of representatives of this series bound to ATAD2 by soaking compounds into protein crystals. Three structures (chloride 9, methyl-containing 15, and bromide analogue 36) are shown in Figure 9. 36 was prepared by the route shown in Scheme 1 using 3-methyl piperidine. Refinement statistics and electron density maps are provided in Table S3 and Figure S9, Supporting Information.
    Consistent with their activity in a peptide-competitive binding assay, 9 and the other compounds from this series bind to the acetyl-lysine pocket of ATAD2. However, they lie deeper than acetyl-lysine and most other bromodomain inhibitors. The four conserved water molecules W1–W4 are all displaced by the phenylsulfonamide group, which lies at the deepest point of the pocket (Figure 9a). The phenyl ring of 9 makes predominantly hydrophobic contacts with Val1008, Phe1009, and Val1013 (Figure 9b). The chlorine atom fills a small indentation normally occupied by the W2 water, whose hydrogen-bonding potential is usually satisfied by three other waters, including W1 and W3, and by the backbone carbonyl of Ile1056. In the absence of W1–W4, the chlorine of 9 binds in a mixed environment, making polar contacts with the backbone carbonyl of Ile1056 and the hydroxyl group of Tyr1021, as well as nonpolar contacts with the hydrophobic side chains of Phe1009, Ala1060, and Ile1056.
    The side-chain NH2 of Asn1064 normally donates a hydrogen bond to inhibitor acceptor groups. In the complex with 9, this group is straddled by the two sulfonamide oxygen atoms (Figure 9b) but the heavy atom distance is over 3.5 Å, which is longer than most hydrogen bonds. One of the sulfonamide oxygens forms a hydrogen bond to the side-chain hydroxyl of Tyr1021, and in this respect, it acts as a mimetic of the W1 water molecule. The hydrogen-bonding potential of the second sulfonamide oxygen is unsatisfied, with carbon atoms of the side chains of Phe1009, Ala1060, and Ile1074 its closest contacts. The sulfonamide dimethylamine group also makes further hydrophobic contacts with the walls of the site, including Val1008 and Ile1074.
    The remaining polar interaction visible in this crystal structure is a hydrogen bond between the amide NH of 9 and the backbone carbonyl of Lys1011 (Figure 9b). Density for the whole ligand was clear up to this amide but was sparse for the hydantoin group, which was modeled into the space available to avoid protein contacts. In this position, one of the hydantoin carbonyl oxygens would be well placed to form a hydrogen bond to the Asp1014 backbone NH.
    The binding mode of 15, shown in Figure 9c, is very similar to that of 9. The azepane ring fills more of the site, making more extensive contacts with the ZA loop residues Tyr1021 and Tyr1063. The methyl group of 15 at the bottom of the pocket superimposes precisely over the chlorine of 9. Again, the hydantoin was not well resolved and could only be modeled.
    The bromide analogue 36 also binds in a very similar way (Figure 9d) but this structure revealed more density for the hydantoin, which permitted its modeling with confidence. One of the two hydantoin carbonyl groups does indeed form a hydrogen bond to the backbone NH of Asp1014, as modeled for 9 and 15, although due to the symmetrical shape of this ring, it is impossible to say if there is any preference for which carbonyl makes this interaction. In the complex with 36, the side chain of Arg1007 adopts a conformation able to form a hydrogen bond to the hydantoin second carbonyl. However, Arg1007 has previously been seen to be highly mobile in complexes with other inhibitors. The density for Arg1007 is similar in the complexes with 36 and 15, but not with 9, suggesting that this interaction is weak and dependent on crystal forces. Alternatively, its formation may depend on the substituents on the hydantoin, but the hydantoin substituents seem to make little difference to ATAD2 potency (Table 3).
    The R2 group of 36 is a mixture of piperidine stereoisomers. The S-enantiomer fitted the density best and so this was modeled, with the methyl piperidine filling similar volume to the azepane of 15 and extending toward Tyr1063.
    The residues whose side chains make contact with 36 are generally conserved or conservatively substituted between ATAD2 and the BET family bromodomains (Table S4, Supporting Information). When 36 was modeled into the BRD4 BD1 site by superimposing the structure of the ATAD2 complex (Figure 9e), the BRD4 side chains of Leu92, Leu94, and Cys136 clash with the inhibitor. Close contacts with Leu92 and Leu94 appear the most significant and are most likely the main reason for the selectivity of the series over the BET bromodomains. These differences arise from the length of the ZA loop, which is two residues longer in the BET bromodomains relative to that in ATAD2.

    Comparison with 37

    While several inhibitors are known that can displace one or more of the conserved acetyl-lysine site water molecules of the BET family and other bromodomains,(37−39) the only previous ATAD2 inhibitor known to displace all four is the triazole 37 (Figure 9), whose Kd was estimated to be 350 μM by NMR.(18) Beyond the common feature that both displace the W1–W4 waters with a substituted phenyl ring, the binding modes of 37 and 36 are quite distinct (Figure 9f). 37 makes a closer hydrogen bond to the side chain of Asn1064 through its triazole nitrogen than 36 but does not interact with residues of the ZA loop such as Tyr1021 or Lys1011. The aniline nitrogen of 37 lies close to the Ile1056 carbonyl oxygen, although the geometry of this interaction is suboptimal for a hydrogen bond. It is striking how closely the bromine of 36 superimposes on the aniline of 37. This bromine extends deeper into the pocket than the chlorine of 9 and the methyl of 15, pushing close to the backbone carbonyl oxygen of Ile1056. The Br–O contact distance (3.1 Å) is less than the sum of their van der Waals radii (3.37 Å). The interaction is also relatively linear (Figure 9f). The distance and angles are consistent with examples of halogen bonding in protein–ligand complex X-ray structures (C–Br–O 149°, Br–O═C 130°, RBr–O 0.91, see also Figures 10c and S10a).(40) Halogen bonds are electrostatic interactions involving a positively charged region of the polarizable bromine atom opposite the C–Br bond (the “sigma hole”), which can form favorable close-range contacts with oxygen atoms (Figure S10a, Supporting Information).(41) Such interactions are rare but have been reported in biological systems, for example, in the complex between BI201335 and HCV NS3-NS4A protease.(42) A more detailed analysis can be found below.

    Quantum Mechanical Analysis of Binding Interactions

    Since this series binds to ATAD2 in a novel way, we carried out calculations based on the crystal structures to investigate the contributions to binding. Molecular mechanics force fields do not consider polarization and charge transfer and cannot accurately handle anisotropic electrostatic interactions such as halogen bonds, so quantum mechanical methods were employed starting with fragment molecular orbital (FMO) calculations.(43) This is a relatively rapid method applicable to protein–ligand complexes in which the protein is divided into fragments, typically single amino acids (although it is important to realize that residues are fragmented between the C and Cα atoms to retain the delocalized character of peptide bonds). Pairwise interaction energies are then calculated between all fragments. Pair interaction energy decomposition analysis (PIEDA) was used to divide the fragment interaction energy into contributions from electrostatic, exchange–repulsion, charge transfer, and correlation/dispersion terms.(44) This calculation does not attempt to estimate the total energy of binding including desolvation and entropic contributions; rather, it describes the quantum mechanical interactions in the bound state. However, this can still provide useful insights into the nature of protein–ligand interactions.(45−47)
    To focus on the interactions between the core of 9, 15, and 36 and their surrounding residues, the inhibitors were trimmed back to the respective methyl-, chloro-, or bromo-phenylsulfonamide fragments, as shown in Figure 10a. The total FMO binding energies between each fragment and each surrounding residue, including two nearby water molecules W5 and W6, are shown in Figure 10b, and the PIEDA energetic decomposition terms are shown in Figure S11a, Supporting Information.
    The profile of interactions for all three inhibitors is very similar, with each analysis highlighting the same strong interactions. The biggest contribution to binding is labeled as Pro1012. Because of the way the protein residues are fragmented, as explained above, this actually represents the hydrogen bond between the inhibitor amide NH and the peptide carbonyl of Lys1011 (Figures 9d and 10d). Desolvation energy would probably reduce the contribution of this interaction in solution.
    Another residue that forms strong interactions with all three inhibitors is Asp1030 (Figure 10e). The PIEDA calculation suggests that this is driven mainly by electrostatic contributions (Figure S11a, Supporting Information). Although nonpolar interactions exist between the side chain of Asp1030 and the phenyl ring of the inhibitor, there are no obvious strong polar interactions. However, again, because of the fragmentation scheme, this interaction includes the contribution from the carbonyl of Met1029, which lies within 3.4 Å of the closest aromatic CH of the inhibitors, which may be polarized by the neighboring bromine.
    The third strongest interaction is with Phe1009, whose side chain approaches the bromine of 36 in an edge-on orientation (Figure 10f). This is the interaction whose magnitude differs most between inhibitors (Figure 10b). As this variation is captured within the electrostatic and dispersion PIEDA components (Figure S11a, Supporting Information), polarization by the inhibitor halogen substituent may play a part. An electrostatic potential map of the ligand surface near Phe1009 is shown in Figure S10b, Supporting Information.
    Despite the geometry between the bromine of 36 and the carbonyl of Ile1056, which is consistent with halogen bonding, the FMO calculations show similar and small interaction energies between Ile1056 and the Br-, Cl-, and Me-substituted fragments (Figure 10b). This suggests that this is not a highly favorable interaction. These calculations did not use high-level basis functions, which are necessary for the accurate treatment of halogen bonding, since these present challenges for FMO.(48,49) Calculations were therefore carried out to look at the Ile1056 interaction with the three fragments, using density functional theory (DFT) with higher-level basis sets using the Counterpoise method.(50) Using this approach, the interaction energies between each fragment and Ile1056 are all favorable. The bromide interaction is larger than chloride or methyl, but the magnitude of all three is rather small (Table 7; also see Figure S11b, Supporting Information).
    Table 7. Counterpoise Interaction Energies (M06-2X-D3/LACV3P**++, kJ/mol) Calculated between Bromide, Chloride, and Methyl Fragments and Ile1056 and Phe1009 Using Jaguar
     BrClMe
    Ile1056–3.39–0.96–3.01
    Phe1009–18.91–16.36–16.11
    The interaction energies with Phe1009 were also calculated and found to be greater than those with Ile1056 (Figure S11b, Supporting Information). Again, the binding energy of the bromide analogue is slightly more favorable than chloride. The geometry and energetics therefore suggest that halogen bonding does exist in the complex between 36 and Ile1056 and that this pairwise interaction is stronger with the bromide than with the chloride or methyl analogues. However, the energetic contribution of the halogen bond is relatively small and does not appear to be among the most significant contributions to binding. Instead, the increased potency of the bromine-substituted analogues seems to be due to contributions from a wider range of interactions including other nearby residues such as Phe1009.

    Discussion and Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    We set out to discover inhibitors of the ATAD2 bromodomain by high-throughput screening, expecting that the low biological tractability of this bromodomain relative to others would translate into a low hit rate. This was the case, but this was masked by a very high hit rate of compounds acting through nonprogressible mechanisms in our assay, which greatly outnumbered the few progressible hits within the screening collection. While this is one of the more challenging examples of this behavior we have seen, it is by no means unusual, highlighting the need to rigorously confirm all screening hits, especially for novel targets whose behavior is unknown. It also showed the value of testing the performance of the screening cascade before the main screen is triggered, so that unanticipated problems can be identified and solved.
    To proceed with confidence, it was essential to have robust orthogonal biophysical confirmation assays. Because these had relatively limited capacity, we also needed to change the primary screen to reduce the hit rate to a manageable level. Resorting to computational triage would have been ineffective in this case: the problematic compounds are diverse and did not match known frequent-hitter structural filters. A clustering or diversity-based selection would have had an insufficient impact, while biasing selection toward known bromodomain pharmacophores would have compromised our ability to find novel modes of action.
    The incidence of nonprogressible hits was reduced by redesigning the ATAD2 bromodomain protein used in the assay. Unexpectedly, for the assays we deployed (NMR, SPR, and TR-FRET), each performed most robustly with a different protein construct. This highlights the need to test the protein for each assay format, ensuring not just reproducible pharmacology with tool compounds but low nonprogressible hit rates and the ability to configure the assay to determine characteristics that can differentiate desirable from nondesirable binding behavior. For example, in the SPR assay, we found that the use of a mutant protein control was very helpful.
    To our knowledge, this is the first screen of a large unbiased compound library against ATAD2 with the exception of one previous report in which DNA-encoded libraries were screened against the GST-tagged bromodomain.(23) Following the capture of the protein using a glutathione matrix, hits were identified by DNA sequencing. Like the work we report here, to confirm binding of the hits when resynthesized off-DNA, a panel of follow-up assays was employed, including a peptide-based TR-FRET assay, protein NMR, microscale thermophoresis, and a thermal shift assay.
    After validation of all steps of the triage, we proceeded to run the HTS. This identified a single series of active and progressible hits that was robustly active in multiple hit qualification assays. Although the initial hit rate from our optimized assay was relatively low at 0.6%, the progressible hit rate was a mere 0.001% of the HTS collection. Despite our efforts to minimize unprogressible mechanisms, specific binding could not be confirmed for 99.8% of the initial hits and 95% of the more potent hits with TR-FRET IC50 < 30 μM. These statistics underline the importance of the careful use of orthogonal hit qualification assays both before and during hit identification and should be a warning to researchers that great caution is needed before trusting reported hits that have not been subjected to a similar rigorous confirmation, especially for low-tractability targets.
    X-ray structures of the hits and analogues show that this series binds in a novel mode, displacing the active-site water network and making different active-site interactions to those usually observed in bromodomain inhibitor complexes. It is unlikely that this series would have been found using prior knowledge, as was also the case for the reported DNA-encoded library screen,(23) showing that diversity screening can add value even to a well-studied protein class like bromodomains.
    The HTS discovered reasonably potent ATAD2 ligands that displace the active-site waters, but to our surprise it did not find any conventionally binding inhibitors. We know that the TR-FRET assay can detect such compounds, as we showed in our report of screening a bromodomain-targeted compound set.(20) This may simply be due to chance, given the extremely low tractability of the target. However, it is possible that the water network in ATAD2 is less stable than other bromodomains, a suggestion supported by molecular dynamics simulations, which ranked the water network of ATAD2 as one of the least stable among bromodomains studied.(51,52) It may indeed be that the penalty for displacing the active-site waters varies between bromodomains, explaining the selectivity of the phenylsulfonamides over the BET family, which bind their waters more tightly in simulations. One caveat is that the simulations were based upon the crystal structure of the ATAD2 981–1108 truncate. We showed above that the length of the truncated ATAD2 bromodomain sequence strongly influenced the nonprogressible hit rate in our binding assay. Though these hits do not bind to the ATAD2 acetyl-lysine site, it would not be surprising if the water network stability, and hence the ability to detect and quantify the potency of inhibitors with different binding modes, also varied with construct length. The influence of construct length upon the stability of bromodomain active-site water networks has not been investigated. In any event, the sulfonamide hits do compete with peptide for binding to full-length endogenous ATAD2 in the bromosphere assay and so should be physiologically relevant.
    The lead molecules contain a bromine atom that engages the ATAD2 bromodomain in a halogen-bonding interaction not previously described in bromodomains. Its binding partner is the backbone carbonyl of Ile1056 in a structurally conserved helix present across the family including the well-studied BET family. Since the carbonyl is only exposed for binding to inhibitors after displacement of the water network, differential sensitivity to water displacement may confer some selectivity for ATAD2, as described above. The SAR shows that bromine improves the binding of the series by up to 10-fold relative to chlorine. However, this was not needed to find the original HTS hits, which only contained chlorine or methyl groups. Quantum mechanics calculations suggest that the contribution of the bromine halogen bond to the overall binding energy is small and that interactions between the bromine and other residues of the site also contribute as much if not more to binding. When describing crystallographic complexes, it is often tempting to give great significance to rare and interesting interactions but this may not always be warranted.
    In summary, we have presented above the discovery of the phenylsulfonamide series of ATAD2 inhibitors by high-throughput screening. The optimization of the series against the bromodomains of ATAD2 and CECR2 will be the subject of a further manuscript.(36)

    Experimental Section

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To

    Chemistry

    All solvents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (Hy-Dry anhydrous solvents), and commercially available reagents were used as received. All reactions were followed by thin-layer chromatography (TLC) analysis (TLC plates GF254, Merck) or liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry (LC/MS) using a Waters ZQ instrument. NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker NanoBay 400 MHz or a Bruker AVII+ 600 MHz spectrometer and are referenced as follows: 1H NMR (400 or 600 MHz), internal standard tetramethylsilane at δ = 0.00; 13C NMR (100.6 or 150.9 MHz), internal standard CDCl3 at δ = 77.23 or dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO)-d6 at δ = 39.70. Column chromatography was performed on prepacked silica gel columns (30–90 mesh, IST) using a Biotage SP4. Mass spectra were recorded on Waters ZQ (electrospray ionization-MS) and Q-Tof 2 [high-resolution mass spectrometry (HRMS)] spectrometers. Mass-directed Auto Prep (MDAP) was performed on a Waters 2767 with a MicroMass ZQ mass spectrometer using a Supelco LCABZ++ column.

    Synthetic Methods and Characterization of Compounds

    Abbreviations for multiplicities observed in NMR spectra: s; singlet; br s, broad singlet; d, doublet; t, triplet; q, quadruplet; p, pentuplet; spt, septuplet; m, multiplet. The purity of all compounds was determined by LC/MS and 1H NMR and was always >95%.

    LC/MS

    Ultraperformance liquid chromatography (UPLC) analysis was conducted on an Acquity UPLC BEH C18 column (50 mm × 2.1 mm, i.d. 1.7 μm packing diameter) at 40 °C. Formate method: solvents employed were A = 0.1% v/v solution of formic acid in water; B = 0.1% v/v solution of formic acid in acetonitrile. High pH method: the solvents employed were A = 10 mM ammonium hydrogen carbonate in water adjusted to pH 10 with ammonia solution; B = acetonitrile. For both methods, the gradient employed was as follows (Table 8).
    Table 8
    time (min)flow rate (mL/min)%A%B
    01991
    1.51397
    1.91397
    2.010100
    The UV detection was a summed signal from a wavelength of 210–350 nm. Mass spectra were obtained on a Waters ZQ instrument; ionization mode, alternate-scan positive and negative electrospray; scan range 100–1000 amu; scan time: 0.27 s; interscan delay: 0.10 s. LC/MS traces are shown in Figure S13, Supporting Information.

    MDAP

    Formate method: high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) analysis was conducted on either a Sunfire C18 column (100 mm × 19 mm, i.d. 5 μm packing diameter) or a Sunfire C18 column (150 mm × 30 mm, i.d. 5 μm packing diameter) at ambient temperature. The solvents employed were A = 0.1% v/v solution of formic acid in water; B = 0.1% v/v solution of formic acid in acetonitrile. It was run as a gradient over either 15 or 25 min (extended run) with a flow rate of 20 mL/min (100 mm × 19 mm, i.d 5 μm packing diameter) or 40 mL/min (150 mm × 30 mm, i.d. 5 μm packing diameter). High pH method: HPLC analysis was conducted on either an Xbridge C18 column (100 mm × 19 mm, i.d. 5 μm packing diameter) or an Xbridge C18 column (100 mm × 30 mm, i.d. 5 μm packing diameter) at ambient temperature. The solvents employed were A = 10 mM ammonium bicarbonate in water, adjusted to pH 10 with ammonia solution; B = acetonitrile. It was run as a gradient over either 15 or 25 min (extended run) with a flow rate of 20 mL/min (100 mm × 19 mm, i.d. 5 μm packing diameter) or 40 mL/min (100 mm × 30 mm, i.d. 5 μm packing diameter). For both methods, UV detection was a summed signal from a wavelength of 210–350 nm. Mass spectra were obtained on a Waters ZQ instrument; ionization mode, alternate-scan positive and negative electrospray; scan range 100–1000 amu; scan time: 0.50 s; interscan delay: 0.20 s.
    Compounds 2–17, 21, 22, 27, and 33 were commercially available. Compound 2 was resynthesized for further characterization.

    (1-Methyl-6-(4-methylpiperazin-1-yl)-1H-pyrazolo[3,4-d]pyrimidin-4-yl)(phenyl)methanone (1)

    1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ ppm 10.84–10.96 (m, 1H), 8.17 (s, 1H), 8.01–8.12 (m, 2H), 7.71–7.83 (m, 1H), 7.53–7.66 (m, 2H), 4.64–4.90 (m, 2H), 3.95 (s, 3H), 3.43–3.59 (m, 4H), 2.99–3.20 (m, 2H), 2.74–2.85 (m, 3H).

    N-(4-Chloro-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)-2-(4-cyclopropyl-4-methyl-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-1-yl)acetamide (2)

    A 20 mL microwave vial was charged with K2CO3 (79 mg, 0.57 mmol), 2-chloro-N-(4-chloro-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)acetamide (commercially available from Enamine, 100 mg, 0.285 mmol), and 5-cyclopropyl-5-methylimidazolidine-2,4-dione (43.9 mg, 0.285 mmol) and was then filled with acetone (10 mL). The resulting mixture was degassed for 20 min with nitrogen and then stirred at 80 °C for 30 min under microwave irradiations before being cooled down to room temperature and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was partitioned between CH2Cl2 (20 mL) and water (20 mL), and the layers were separated. The organic phase was dried using a phase separator and concentrated in vacuo. Purification of the residue by flash chromatography on silica gel (25 g column, gradient: 0–100% CH2Cl2 in cyclohexane) gave N-(4-chloro-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)-2-(4-cyclopropyl-4-methyl-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-1-yl)acetamide (92 mg, 69%) as a white solid. LC/MS (method high pH): retention time 1.04 min, [M + H]+ = 469.21.
    1H NMR (600 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.71 (s, 1H), 8.23 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 1H), 8.17 (s, 1H), 7.83 (dd, J = 8.6, 2.8 Hz, 1H), 7.64 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H), 4.15–4.24 (m, 2H), 3.13–3.20 (m, 4H), 1.46–1.58 (m, 6H), 1.40 (s, 3H), 1.16 (tt, J = 8.3, 5.3 Hz, 1H), 0.41–0.51 (m, 2H), 0.33–0.39 (m, 1H), 0.26–0.33 (m, 1H).

    (R)-N-(4-Chloro-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)-2-(4-cyclopropyl-4-methyl-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-1-yl)acetamide and (S)-N-(4-Chloro-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)-2-(4-cyclopropyl-4-methyl-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-1-yl)acetamide (18 and 19)

    N-(4-Chloro-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)-2-(4-cyclopropyl-4-methyl-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-1-yl)acetamide (2, 25 mg) was separated into its two enantiomers by chiral chromatography. Analytical method: approximately 0.5 mg of material was dissolved in 1:1 EtOH/heptane (1 mL), and 20 μL was injected onto the column. Eluant: 20% EtOH in heptane, flow f = 1.0 mL/min, wavelength 215 nm. Column 4.6 mm × 25 cm i.d. Chiralpak AD-H. Preparative method: approximately 25 mg of material was dissolved in EtOH (1 mL) and heptane (1 mL). A solution of 1 mL was injected onto the column. Eluant: 20% EtOH in heptane, flow = 30 mL/min, wavelength 215 nm. Column 30 mm × 25 cm Chiralpak AD-H. The total number of injections is 2. The fractions containing products were combined and concentrated in vacuo to give compound 18 (10 mg, 80%) as the fastest running enantiomer and compound 19 (11 mg, 88%) as the slowest running enantiomer. LC/MS (method high pH): retention time 1.04 min, [M + H]+ = 469.1.

    2-(4-Cyclopropyl-4-methyl-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-1-yl)-N-(3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)-4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)acetamide (20)

    A mixture of N-(4-bromo-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)-2-(4-cyclopropyl-4-methyl-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-1-yl)acetamide (23, 300 mg, 0.584 mmol) and CuI (334 mg, 1.75 mmol) in DMF (2 mL) at room temperature was treated with methyl fluorosulfonyl difluoroacetate (0.594 mL, 4.67 mmol) in DMF (2 mL) dropwise over 1 min. The resulting mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 12 h and then cooled down to room temperature and diluted with EtOAc. The organic phase was washed with water (25 mL) and then brine (25 mL), dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. Purification of the residue by preparative HPLC gave 2-(4-cyclopropyl-4-methyl-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-1-yl)-N-(3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)-4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)acetamide (43 mg, 15%) as an off-white solid. LC/MS (method formic): retention time 1.02 min, [M + H]+ = 503.4. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.28 (d, J = 1.8 Hz, 1H), 8.22 (s, 1H), 7.93–8.08 (m, 2H), 4.17–4.36 (m, 2H), 3.14–3.25 (m, 5H), 1.49–1.70 (m, 7H), 1.44 (s, 3H), 0.43–0.55 (m, 2H), 0.28–0.43 (m, 2H).

    N-(4-Bromo-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)-2-(4-cyclopropyl-4-methyl-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-1-yl)acetamide (23)

    Step 1: 2-bromo-5-nitrobenzenesulfonyl chloride (commercially available, 1.10 g, 3.66 mmol) was taken up in CH2Cl2 (50 mL) under nitrogen and cooled to 0 °C. DIPEA (1.41 mL, 8.05 mmol) was added, and the reaction was stirred for 5 min before piperidine (0.43 mL, 4.39 mmol) was added. The reaction was stirred at 0 °C for 1 h. The reaction mixture was quenched with a saturated NaHCO3 aqueous solution (50 mL) and extracted with CH2Cl2 (2 × 50 mL). The combined organics were filtered through a hydrophobic frit and concentrated in vacuo to afford 1-((2-bromo-5-nitrophenyl)sulfonyl)piperidine (1.24 g, 97%) as an orange gum, which was used in the next step without further purifiction. LC/MS (method formic): retention time 1.24 min, [M + H]+ = 349.0 (1Br). HRMS (C11H13BrN2O4S): [M + H]+ calcd 348.9858, found 348.9844; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.91 (d, J = 2.7 Hz, 1H), 8.22 (dd, J = 8.6, 2.7 Hz, 1H), 7.96 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 3.32–3.40 (m, 4H), 1.57–1.73 (m, 6H). 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 146.8, 140.8, 137.0, 127.7, 127.2, 126.7, 46.8, 25.6, 23.7. Step 2: 1-((2-bromo-5-nitrophenyl)sulfonyl)piperidine (1.10 g, 3.15 mmol), NH4Cl (0.25 g, 4.73 mmol), and Fe(0) (0.53 g, 9.45 mmol) were dissolved in a 3:1 mixture of EtOH (5.0 mL) and water (1.7 mL). The resulting solution was heated to 70 °C for 2 h. The reaction was allowed to cool down to room temperature and then filtered through a plug of celite, washing with MeOH (20 mL). The resulting solution was concentrated in vacuo and then partitioned between a saturated NaHCO3 aqueous solution (20 mL) and CH2Cl2 (20 mL). The layers were separated, and the aqueous phase was extracted with CH2Cl2 (2 × 20 mL). The combined organics were passed through a hydrophobic frit and concentrated in vacuo to afford the crude product. The crude product was purified by flash chromatography on silica gel, eluting with 0–50% EtOAc/cyclohexane. The pure fractions were combined and concentrated in vacuo to afford 4-bromo-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)aniline (0.75 g, 74%) as an orange gum. LC/MS (method formic): retention time 1.02 min, [M + H]+ = 319.1 (1Br). HRMS (C11H15BrN2O2S): [M + H]+ calcd 319.0116, found 319.0112; 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 7.39–7.48 (m, 2H), 6.67 (dd, J = 8.6, 2.9 Hz, 1H), 3.93 (br s, 2H), 3.23–3.30 (m, 4H), 1.52–1.69 (m, 6H); 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 145.9, 138.3, 136.2, 119.4, 118.3, 106.9, 46.5, 25.5, 23.8; IR νmax (cm–1) 3374, 2938, 1626, 1590, 1463, 1309, 1140, 719, 578. Step 3: 2-(4-cyclopropyl-4-methyl-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-1-yl)acetic acid (commercially available, 319 mg, 1.50 mmol), 4-bromo-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)aniline (400 mg, 1.25 mmol), and HATU (572 mg, 1.50 mmol) were dissolved in CH2Cl2 (10 mL). DIPEA (0.657 mL, 3.76 mmol) was added, and the resulting solution was stirred at room temperature for 2 h. The reaction was quenched with a saturated NaHCO3 aqueous solution (20 mL) and extracted with CH2Cl2 (3 × 20 mL). The combined organics were passed through a hydrophobic frit and concentrated in vacuo to afford the crude product. The crude product was purified by flash chromatography on silica gel, eluting with 0–60% EtOAc/cyclohexane. The pure fractions were combined and concentrated in vacuo to afford N-(4-bromo-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)-2-(4-cyclopropyl-4-methyl-2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-1-yl)acetamide (405 mg, 63%) as a cream solid. LC/MS (method formic): retention time 1.05 min, [M + H]+ = 513.2 (1Br). HRMS (C20H25BrN4O5S): [M + H]+ calcd 513.0807, found 513.0807; 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.71 (s, 1H), 8.98 (s, 1H), 7.91–8.01 (m, 2H), 7.62 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 4.19 (s, 2H), 3.15–3.21 (m, 4H), 1.48–1.56 (m, 6H), 1.40 (s, 3H), 1.12–1.19 (m, 1H), 0.41–0.48 (m, 2H), 0.34–0.39 (m, 1H), 0.26–0.33 (m, 1H); 13C NMR (101 MHz, CDCl3) δ 176.4, 164.6, 156.5, 138.1, 137.5, 136.3, 124.5, 122.8, 113.9, 62.0, 46.6, 41.5, 25.5, 23.7, 23.0, 17.3, 1.1, 0.3; m.p. 221.5 – 225.0 °C; IR νmax (cm–1) 3308, 1712, 1535, 1454, 1307, 579.

    N-(3-(Piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)-4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)propionamide (28)

    A solution of N-(4-bromo-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (32, 200 mg, 0.533 mmol), copper iodide (304 mg, 1.60 mmol), and methyl fluorosulfonyl difluoroacetate (819 mg, 4.26 mmol) in DMF (2 mL) was stirred at 80 °C for 26 h and then cooled down to room temperature, and diluted with EtOAc. The organic phase was washed with water and brine, dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. Purification of the residue by preparative HPLC (column Xbridge C8 (250 mm × 19 mm2, i.d. 10 μm), mobile phase 0.1% trifluoroacetyl (TFA) in water and CH3CN) gave N-(3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)-4-(trifluoromethyl)phenyl)propionamide (19 mg, 10%) as an off-white solid. LC/MS (method formic): retention time 1.08 min, [M + H]+ = 365.31. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.12 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 8.02–8.08 (m, 1H), 7.81 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 7.58–7.67 (m, 1H), 3.20–3.30 (m, 4H), 2.46 (q, J = 7.6 Hz, 2H), 1.49–1.71 (m, 6H), 1.27 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 3H).

    N-(4-Fluoro-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (29)

    Step 1: a solution of piperidine (0.231 mL, 2.33 mmol) and NEt3 (0.974 mL, 6.99 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (20 mL) at 0 °C was treated with 2-fluoro-5-nitrobenzene-1-sulfonyl chloride (available from Combi Block, 0.67 g, 2.8 mmol) dropwise. The resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 16 h and then treated with ice-cold water (50 mL). The layers were separated. The aqueous phase was extracted with CH2Cl2 (2 × 30 mL), and the combined organics were dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated in vacuo. Purification of the residue by flash chromatography on silica gel (20 g column, gradient: 5–12% EtOAc in petroleum ether) gave 1-((2-fluoro-5-nitrophenyl)sulfonyl)piperidine (0.3 g, 37%) as pale yellow solid. Step 2: a suspension of 1-((2-fluoro-5-nitrophenyl)sulfonyl)piperidine (0.30 g, 1.0 mmol) in EtOH (15 mL) and water (5 mL) was treated at room temperature with Fe(0) (0.291 g, 5.20 mmol) and NH4Cl (0.056 g, 1.0 mmol), and the resulting mixture was stirred at 70 °C for 1 h and then cooled down to room temperature. The insolubles were filtered off using celite and washed with MeOH (50 mL). The phases were combined, and most of the volatiles were removed in vacuo. The residue was diluted with ice-cold water, and the aqueous phase was extracted with EtOAc (2 × 40 mL). The combined organic layers were dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated in vacuo. Trituration of the residue with pentane gave 4-fluoro-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)aniline (0.18 g, 67%) as a gray sticky solid, which was used in the next step without further purification. Step 3: a solution of 4-fluoro-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)aniline (0.26 g, 1.0 mmol) and NEt3 (0.281 mL, 2.01 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (20 mL) at 0 °C was treated with propionyl chloride (0.105 mL, 1.208 mmol) dropwise. The reaction was warmed to room temperature, stirred for 1 h, and then treated with ice-cold water (30 mL). The layers were separated, and the aqueous phase was extracted with CH2Cl2 (2 × 30 mL). The combined organics were dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by preparative TLC (50% EtOAc in petroleum ether) to give N-(4-fluoro-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (123 mg, 39%) as an off-white solid. LC/MS (method formic): retention time 0.91 min, [M + H]+ = 315.08. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.09 (dt, J = 8.4, 3.5 Hz, 1H), 7.68 (dd, J = 5.9, 2.9 Hz, 1H), 7.45–7.59 (m, 1H), 7.17 (t, J = 9.2 Hz, 1H), 3.07–3.27 (m, 4H), 2.42 (q, J = 7.7 Hz, 2H), 1.64 (quin, J = 5.6 Hz, 4H), 1.45–1.53 (m, 2H), 1.26 (t, J =7.6 Hz, 3H).

    N-(4-Hydroxy-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (30)

    A solution of N-(4-bromo-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (32, 400 mg, 1.07 mmol) in 1, 4-dioxane (2.5 mL) and water (2.5 mL) at room temperature was treated with KOH (179 mg, 3.20 mmol), Pd2(dba)3 (19.5 mg, 0.0210 mmol), and t-butylXphos (9 mg, 0.021 mmol). The resulting mixture was stirred at 100 °C for 12 h, then cooled down to room temperature, and diluted with water (20 mL). The aqueous phase was extracted with EtOAc (2 × 50 mL), and the combined organics were dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated in vacuo. Purification of the residue by flash chromatography on silica gel (gradient: 40% EtOAc in hexanes) gave a residue, which was further purified by preparative HPLC (column Packed C18 (250 mm × 19 mm, i.d. 5 μm), mobile phase: (A) 0.1% TFA in water, (B) acetonitrile) to give N-(4-hydroxy-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (70 mg, 21%) as a brown solid. LC/MS (method formic): retention time 0.80 min, [M + H]+ = 313.11. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.54–8.95 (m, 1H), 7.73 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 7.50 (dd, J = 8.8, 2.4 Hz, 1H), 7.08 (br s, 1H), 7.00 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H), 3.03–3.17 (m, 4H), 2.40 (q, J = 7.7 Hz, 2H), 1.66 (dt, J = 11.3, 5.8 Hz, 4H), 1.41–1.53 (m, 2H), 1.26 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 3H).

    N-(4-Amino-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (31)

    A solution of N-(4-bromo-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (35, 200 mg, 0.533 mmol), K2CO3 (221 mg, 1.60 mmol), and l-proline (123 mg, 1.07 mmol) in 25% w/w ammonia (7.96 mL, 53.3 mmol) at room temperature was treated with CuI (203 mg, 1.07 mmol), and the resulting mixture was stirred at 110 °C for 12 h in a sealed tube, then cooled down to room temperature, and diluted with water (50 mL). The aqueus phase was extracted with EtOAc (2 × 50 mL), and the combined organics were washed with brine (20 mL), dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. Purification of the residue by preparative TLC gave N-(4-amino-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (37 mg, 22%) as an off-white solid. LC/MS (method formic): retention time 0.78 min, [M + H]+ = 312.12. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 9.67 (s, 1H), 7.71 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 1H), 7.48 (dd, J = 8.8, 2.4 Hz, 1H), 6.79 (d, J = 8.8 Hz, 1H), 5.79 (s, 2H), 2.91–3.08 (m, 4H), 2.25 (q, J = 7.7 Hz, 2H), 1.46–1.60 (m, 4H), 1.33–1.43 (m, 2H), 1.06 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 3H).

    N-(4-Cyano-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (32)

    A solution of N-(4-bromo-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (35, 200 mg, 0.533 mmol) in NMP (2 mL) at room temperature under nitrogen was treated with copper(I) cyanide (71.6 mg, 0.799 mmol), and the resulting mixture was stirred at 160 °C for 1 h, then cooled down to room temperature, and diluted with water (50 mL). The aqueous phase was extracted with EtOAc (2 × 100 mL), and the combined organics were washed with brine (50 mL), dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. Purification of the residue by flash chromatography on silica gel (gradient 60% EtOAc in hexanes) gave N-(4-cyano-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (107 mg, 62%) as an off-white solid. LC/MS (method formic): retention time 0.92 min, [M + H]+ = 322.31. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.28 (dd, J = 8.4, 2.1 Hz, 1H), 7.96 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 7.86 (m, 2H), 3.26–3.31 (m, 4H), 2.52 (q, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 1.70 (quin, J = 5.6 Hz, 4H), 1.52–1.62 (m, 2H), 1.31 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 3H).

    N-(4-Ethyl-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (34)

    Step 1: a mixture of 1-ethyl-4-nitrobenzene (1.79 mL, 13.2 mmol) and sulfurochloridic acid (3.23 mL, 39.7 mmol) was heated at 100 °C for 4 h, then cooled down to room temperature, and concentrated in vacuo to give 2-ethyl-5-nitrobenzene-1-sulfonyl chloride (1.8 g, 54%) as a gray solid, which was used in the next step without further purification. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.93 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 8.49 (dd, J = 8.6, 2.4 Hz, 1H), 7.71 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 3.31 (q, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 1.42 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 3H). Step 2: a suspension of 2-ethyl-5-nitrobenzene-1-sulfonyl chloride (1.8 g, 7.2 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (20 mL) at 0 °C was treated with NEt3 (2.51 mL, 18.0 mmol) and then piperidine (0.595 mL, 6.01 mmol), and the resulting mixture was stirred at room temperature for 1 h before being treated with ice-cold water (100 mL). The layers were separated, and the aqueous phase was extracted with CH2Cl2 (2 × 100 mL). The combined organics were dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated in vacuo. Tritration of the residue with Et2O and pentane gave 1-((2-ethyl-5-nitrophenyl)sulfonyl)piperidine (1.1 g, 61%) as a yellow solid, which was used in the next step without further purification. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 8.49 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 8.42 (dd, J = 8.4, 2.5 Hz, 1H), 7.82 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 3.10–3.17 (m, 4H), 3.06 (q, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 1.43–1.60 (m, 6H), 1.25 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 3H). Step 3: a solution of 1-((2-ethyl-5-nitrophenyl)sulfonyl)piperidine (1.1 g, 4.4 mmol) in EtOH (15 mL) and water (5 mL) at room temperature was treated with Fe(0) (1.23 g, 22.0 mmol) and NH4Cl (0.354 g, 6.61 mmol), and the resulting mixture was stirred at 70 °C for 1 h and then cooled down to room temperature. The insolubles were filtered off through celite and rinsed with MeOH (100 mL), and most of the volatiles were removed in vacuo. The residue was diluted with ice-cold water (100 mL), and the aqueous phase was extracted with EtOAc (2 × 150 mL). The combined organics were dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated in vacuo. Trituration of the residue with pentane gave 4-ethyl-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)aniline (0.8 g, 68%) as a yellow sticky solid, which was used in the next step without further purification. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 7.08 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 1H), 7.01 (d, J = 2.4 Hz, 1H), 6.75 (dd, J = 8.3, 2.4 Hz, 1H), 5.35 (s, 2H), 2.94–3.04 (m, 4H), 2.75 (q, J = 7.4 Hz, 2H), 1.43–1.60 (m, 6H), 1.11 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 3H). Step 4: a solution of 4-ethyl-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)aniline (0.80 g, 3.0 mmol) and NEt3 (0.831 mL, 5.96 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (30 mL) at 0 °C under nitrogen was treated with propionyl chloride (0.305 mL, 3.58 mmol) dropwise. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 30 min and then treated with ice-cold water (50 mL). The layers were separated, and the aqueous phase was extracted with CH2Cl2 (2 × 50 mL). The combined organics were dried over Na2SO4 and concentrated in vacuo. Trituration of the residue with Et2O gave N-(4-ethyl-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (412 mg, 42%) as a white solid. LC/MS (method formic): retention time 1.01 min, [M + H]+ = 325.12. 1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6), δ 10.08 (s, 1H), 8.08 (d, J = 2.2 Hz, 1H), 7.79 (dd, J = 8.3, 2.2 Hz, 1H), 7.40 (d, J = 8.6 Hz, 1H), 2.99–3.13 (m, 4H), 2.88 (q, J = 7.5 Hz, 2H), 2.22–2.40 (m, 2H), 1.33–1.62 (m, 6H), 1.17 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 3H), 1.08 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 3H).

    N-(4-Bromo-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (35)

    A solution of 4-bromo-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)aniline (3.60 g, 11.3 mmol) and NEt3 (4.72 mL, 33.8 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (40 mL) at 0 °C was treated with propionyl chloride (1.25 g, 13.5 mmol), and the resulting mixture was stirred at this temperature for 1 h and then quenched with water (100 mL). The layers were separated, and the aqueous phase was extracted with EtOAc (2 × 250 mL). The combined organics were washed with brine (200 mL), dried over Na2SO4, and concentrated in vacuo. Purification of the residue by flash chromatography on silica gel (gradient 0–100% EtOAc in hexanes) gave N-(4-bromo-3-(piperidin-1-ylsulfonyl)phenyl)propionamide (3.3 g, 76%) as an off-white solid. LC/MS (method formic): retention time 1.00 min, [M + H]+ = 376.99 (1Br). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3) δ 8.06 (dd, J = 8.7, 2.5 Hz, 1H), 7.99 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 1H), 7.66–7.78 (m, 2H), 3.27–3.36 (m, 4H), 2.48 (q, J = 7.6 Hz, 2H), 1.54–1.73 (m, 6H), 1.30 (t, J = 7.6 Hz, 3H).

    N-(4-Bromo-3-((3-methylpiperidin-1-yl)sulfonyl)phenyl)-2-(2,5-dioxoimidazolidin-1-yl)acetamide (36)

    1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ 10.62 (br s, 1H), 8.27 (d, J = 2.6 Hz, 1H), 8.17 (s, 1H), 7.76–7.85 (m, 1H), 7.72 (dd, J = 8.6, 2.6 Hz, 1H), 4.20 (s, 2H), 4.02 (s, 2H), 3.45–3.65 (m, 2H), 2.63–2.80 (m, 1H), 2.40 (dd, J = 12.3, 10.3 Hz, 1H), 1.52–1.77 (m, 3H), 1.34–1.52 (m, 1H), 0.92–1.11 (m, 1H), 0.84 (d, J = 6.6 Hz, 3H).

    2-(4-((Dimethylamino)methyl)phenyl)-5,6-dimethylpyrimidin-4(3H)-one (38)

    1H NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d6) δ ppm 12.45 (br s, 1H), 8.05 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 2H), 7.41 (d, J = 8.3 Hz, 2H), 3.45 (s, 2H), 2.29 (s, 3H), 2.16 (s, 6H), 1.98 (s, 3H).

    Protein Cloning, Expression, and Purification

    Methods for the production of 6His-FLAG-Tev-ATAD2(950–1148), FLAG-6His-Tev-ATAD2(981–1121), and 15N labeled and unlabeled ATAD2(981–1108) have all been published.(20,21)
    For the new constructs listed in Table S1 (Supporting Information), all except for construct 7 were cloned into the pET26b vector using restriction enzymes NdeI and XhoI with the FLAG-6H-tev tag added with the 5′ primer. Construct 7 was cloned into the pET11c vector using NdeI and BamHI. Plasmid DNA was transformed into Escherichia coli BL21 (DE3)-competent cells (Invitrogen C6000-03) and recombinant colonies selected on Luria-Bertani (LB)-agar plates containing the relevant antibiotic. For small-scale expression studies, 5 mL of LB medium containing the relevant antibiotic was inoculated with a single colony and grown overnight at 37 °C with shaking at 180 rpm. One milliliter of the overnight culture was used to inoculate 99 mL of the culture medium (LB, 1% (v/v) glycerol or Turbo (USBiological Life Sciences, cat no. P9102-40B), and 1% (v/v) glycerol) and relevant antibiotic, and growth was maintained at 37 °C until absorbance (600 nm) was measured approximately 0.5. The cultures were induced with 0.5 mM isopropyl β-d-thiogalactoside and further incubated at 18 °C overnight. The cultures were harvested by centrifugation, and the pellet was stored at −80 °C. The pellet was resuspended with one-fifth of the expression culture volume buffer A (50 mM Tris–HCl pH 7.5, 300 mM NaCl, 2 mM β-mercaptoethanol). The lysate was sonicated, on ice, for a total of 2 min, at 40% amplitude, and clarified by centrifugation at 39 191g, 4 °C, for 30 min.
    Ni-NTA resin (Qiagen cat. no. 70666) was equilibrated with buffer A. The lysate supernatant was contacted with the resin at 4 °C for 1 h. The nonabsorbed fraction was collected via a gravity column, and the column was washed with 10 column volumes buffer A. The column was further washed with 10 column volumes buffer A containing 20 mM Imidazole. Bound ATAD2 protein was eluted with a step gradient of buffer B (50 mM Tris–HCl pH 7.5, 300 mM NaCl, 100 mM ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid, and 5 mM β-mercaptoethanol) over 10 column volumes. Protein identity was confirmed by peptide mass fingerprinting and LC/MS analysis.

    Assays

    Methods for the Flag-6H-tev-ATAD2(981–1121) peptide competition time-resolved fluorescence resonance energy transfer (TR-FRET) binding assay, SPR binding assay, 15N–1H HSQC NMR (50 μM protein), and bromosphere assay, as well as the mutant BET bromodomain TR-FRET assays, are available elsewhere.(20,21)

    Evaluation of Nonbiotinylated H4 Peptide Binding to Newly Prepared ATAD2 Constructs by TR-FRET

    Variations of the previously described Flag-6H-tev-ATAD2(981–1121) peptide competition TR-FRET assay were used. Each ATAD2 construct (25 nM) was prepared in an assay buffer [composed of 50 mM N-(2-hydroxyethyl)piperazine-N′-ethanesulfonic acid (HEPES), pH 7.4, 150 mM NaCl, 5% glycerol, 1 mM dithiothreitol, and 1 mM 3-[(3-cholamidopropyl)dimethylammonio]-1-propanesulfonate] prior to addition to an equivalent volume of 50 nM biotinylated triacetylated histone H4 peptide (SGRG-K(Ac)-GG-K(Ac)-GLG-K(Ac)-GGAKRHRKV-biotin, CRB Discovery), diluted in the assay buffer. Titrations of nonbiotinylated, triacetylated histone H4 peptide were prepared, from a starting concentration of 1.25 mM, before adding to each of the ATAD2 construct–histone H4 peptide mixtures in a low-volume black 384-well microplate (Greiner Bio-One). Microplates were then centrifuged for 1 min at 1000 rpm before incubation at room temperature for 30 min, taking care to minimize both evaporation and exposure to light. Detection solution, prepared in assay buffer and consisting of 1.25 nM europium chelate-labeled anti-6His antibody (PerkinElmer, W1024, AD0111) and 40 nM LANCE APC surelight–streptavidin (PerkinElmer, CR130-100), was added to each well. Competition between biotinylated and nonbiotinylated histone H4 peptide for binding to each of the ATAD2 constructs was detected on a TRF laser equipped with a PerkinElmer Envision multimode plate reader by excitation at 337 nm, before measuring fluorescence emission at both 615 and 665 nm. The TR-FRET ratio was calculated using the equation: ratio = ((acceptor fluorescence at 665 nm)/(donor fluorescence at 615 nm)) × 1000.

    Evaluation of Small-Molecule Binding to Newly Prepared ATAD2 Constructs by TR-FRET

    The following assay protocol was used to screen the robustness and bromodomain toolsets against ATAD2 constructs 1–10. Fifty nL of 1 mM test compound in 100% DMSO was added to a low-volume 384-well microplate using a Labcyte Echo 555 acoustic dispenser. A Thermo Scientific Multidrop Combi was used to dispense 5 μL of a premixed solution of ATAD2 bromodomain construct and triacetylated histone H4 peptide, prepared in assay buffer (described above). The concentrations of ATAD2 protein and triacetylated histone H4 peptide were determined from the nonbiotinylated peptide competition studies and are detailed in Table S5, Supporting Information. After equilibrating the ATAD2 bromodomain construct and triacetylated histone H4 peptide reagents with a test compound for 30 min in the dark at room temperature, small-molecule competition with the bromodomain protein/biotinylated H4 peptide interaction was monitored using TR-FRET. Detection solution (described above) was added to the 384-well microplate in an equal volume to the protein/peptide solution using the same liquid-handling dispenser. The TR-FRET ratio was measured and calculated as described above. To normalize the assay-specific response in compound screening experiments, the means of the specific microplate positive and negative controls were utilized to convert the response to a percentage inhibition (%I) by applying the equation %I = ((μ1 – X)/(μ1 – μ2)) × 100 (where X is the assay-specific response, μ1 is the mean of the negative, or uninhibited control, and μ2 is the mean of the positive, or inhibited control). Compound screening assay quality was monitored using two control populations on every microplate tested to calculate a “Z′-factor”, defined by the equation Z′ = 1 – (((3 × σ1) + (3 × σ2))/(μ1 – μ2)) (where σ1 and σ2 are the standard deviations of the positive and negative controls, respectively, μ1 is the mean of the negative, or uninhibited control, and μ2 is the mean of the positive, or inhibited control).

    Isothermal Titration Calorimetry

    ATAD2 protein was dialyzed into 50 mM HEPES pH 7.5, 500 mM NaCl, 1 mM tris(2-carboxyethyl)phosphine (TCEP) to give ∼100 μM working solutions. Triacetylated histone H4 peptides were diluted at least 10-fold from a high-concentration aqueous stock solution into 50 mM HEPES pH 7.5, 500 mM NaCl, 1 mM TCEP to give 0.5–2 mM working solutions. For protein constructs and peptide sequences, see Figure S1, Supporting Information.
    ITC data were acquired at 15 °C on a MicroCal auto-iTC. ATAD2 solutions (350 μL) and 140 μL of the peptide solutions were added to wells of a NUNC 96 × 1 mL deep-well plate. The plate was transferred to the plate tray of the auto-iTC instrument at 10 °C. A total of 19 injections of the peptide into ATAD2 protein were made at a reference power of 6 μCal/s, with an initial delay of 60 s and a stirring speed of 500 rpm, in a high-feedback mode. The first injection was 0.5 μL of duration 1 s, with a 120 s spacing and a 2 s filter period. All subsequent injections used 2 μL volumes with a duration of 4 s and a spacing of 120 and 5 s filter periods.
    Raw data binding isotherms were exported into Microcal Origin and fitted to a one-site binding model.

    X-ray Crystallography

    Apo crystals of detagged ATAD2(981–1108) were typically grown at 4 °C in 96-well MRC plates using well solutions under a range of conditions spanning 0.1 M Tris–HCl pH 7.0–8.0, 1.2–1.5 M ammonium sulfate, and 20–25% poly(ethylene glycol)3350 at a protein concentration of 5–6 mg/mL. The sitting drops were made up of a 3:1 ratio of protein/well solution, and the hexagonal crystals often grew from phase-separated drops. To obtain crystal structures of ATAD2 complexed with inhibitors by soaking, compounds were soaked into apo crystals overnight either from solid or using 1–5 mM ligand diluted from a 100–200 mM DMSO stock solution. Soaked crystals were harvested in a cryo-loop and briefly transferred into a cryoprotectant buffer of 20% ethylene glycol + 80% well solution before being plunge-frozen in liquid nitrogen. Data from single crystals were collected at 100 K at the Diamond Light Source (DLS, Oxford) or on an in-house RIGAKU FR-E+ SUPERBRIGHT/Saturn A200 detector/ACTOR robotic system. Data processing was achieved using XDS(53) within AUTOPROC (Global Phasing Limited) and scaled using SCALA(54) or AIMLESS(55) within the CCP4 programming suite.(56) Structures were solved by Fourier synthesis using REFMAC(57) via CCP4 starting from a previously determined in-house structure. Model building was performed using COOT(58) and refined using REFMAC. Statistics for the data collection and refined coordinates, as well as density maps, are shown in Table S3 and Figure S9, Supporting Information. Crystal structures have been deposited in the Protein Data Bank with accession codes 6S55, 6S56, and 6S57.

    Quantum Mechanics Calculations

    Crystal structures were prepared using the Schrödinger Maestro protein preparation tool.(59) Water molecules apart from the two closest to the inhibitor (W5 and W6, Figure 10e) were deleted, and hydrogen placement and H-bond assignment were performed using PROPKA at pH 7.0. Water orientations were sampled, and the preferred orientations were checked for consistency between the three complexes. Minimization was then carried out under the OPLS3 force field with heavy atoms restrained to 0.3 Å root-mean-square deviation. Residues apart from those shown in Figure 10b were deleted, and the remainder capped with methyl groups. The three ligands were truncated to the common substructure shown in Figure 10a, extracted from the protein, and optimized in Jaguar (M06-2X/CC-PVTZ-PP), keeping the red substructure atoms fixed before merging them back into the protein structure.(60) Frontier molecular orbital (FMO) calculations were set up using Facio (v19.2.1), and energy decomposition analysis was performed using GAMESS (v11) using SCS-MP2/6-31G**.(61,62) Counterpoise binding energies between each ligand and selected binding site residues were calculated using a posteriori-corrected DFT and basis sets listed in Figure S11b, Supporting Information. Electrostatic potential maps for inhibitor fragments and protein residues were generated using single-point gas-phase calculations (M06-2X-D3/LACV3P**++).

    AAA nuclear coregulator cancer-associated protein

    ATAD2

    ATPase family AAA domain-containing 2

    bromodomain and extraterminal domain

    BRDx

    bromodomain-containing protein x

    BPTF

    bromodomain PHD finger transcription factor

    BRPF1/2/3

    bromodomain and PHD finger-containing 1/2/3

    CECR2

    cat eye syndrome chromosome region, candidate 2

    CREB binding protein

    KAc

    acetyl lysine

    pIC50

    –log 10 IC50

    SPR

    Surface plasmon resonance

    TAF

    TATA box binding protein (TBP)-associated factor

    This article references 62 other publications.

    1. 1
      Lipinski, C. A. Rule of five in 2015 and beyond: Target and ligand structural limitations, ligand chemistry structure and drug discovery project decisions. Adv. Drug Delivery Rev. 2016, 101, 34– 41,  DOI: 10.1016/j.addr.2016.04.029
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      1
      Rule of five in 2015 and beyond: Target and ligand structural limitations, ligand chemistry structure and drug discovery project decisions
      Lipinski, Christopher A.
      Advanced Drug Delivery Reviews (2016), 101 (), 34-41CODEN: ADDREP; ISSN:0169-409X. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The rule of five (Ro5), based on physicochem. profiles of phase II drugs, is consistent with structural limitations in protein targets and the drug target ligands. Three of four parameters in Ro5 are fundamental to the structure of both target and drug binding sites. The chem. structure of the drug ligand depends on the ligand chem. and design philosophy. Two extremes of chem. structure and design philosophy exist; ligands constructed in the medicinal chem. synthesis lab. without input from natural selection and natural product (NP) metabolites biosynthesized based on evolutionary selection. Exceptions to Ro5 are found mostly among NPs. Chem. chameleon-like behavior of some NPs due to intra-mol. hydrogen bonding as exemplified by cyclosporine A is a strong contributor to NP Ro5 outliers. The fragment derived, drug Navitoclax is an example of the extensive expertise, resources, time and key decisions required for the rare discovery of a non-NP Ro5 outlier.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xnslantr8%253D&md5=72eeb37cd0cd2442ef5c7a199b61f1e3
    2. 2
      Aldrich, C.; Bertozzi, C.; Georg, G. I.; Kiessling, L.; Lindsley, C.; Liotta, D.; Merz, K. M., Jr.; Schepartz, A.; Wang, S. The ecstasy and agony of assay interference compounds. J. Med. Chem. 2017, 60, 2165– 2168,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jmedchem.7b00229
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      2
      The Ecstasy and Agony of Assay Interference Compounds
      Aldrich, Courtney; Bertozzi, Carolyn; Georg, Gunda I.; Kiessling, Laura; Lindsley, Craig; Liotta, Dennis; Merz, Kenneth M.; Schepartz, Alanna; Wang, Shaomeng
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2017), 60 (6), 2165-2168CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      The ecstasy of discovering a new hit from screening can lead to a highly productive research effort to discover new bioactive compds. However, in too many cases this ecstasy is followed by the agony of realizing that the compds. are not active against the desired target. Many of these false hits are Pan Assay INterference compds. (PAINS) 1 or colloidal aggregators. Whether the screen is conducted in silico or in the lab. and whether screening libraries, natural products, or drugs are used, all discovery efforts that rely on some form of screening to identify bioactivity are susceptible to this phenomenon. Studies that omit crit. controls against exptl. artifacts caused by PAINS may waste years of research effort as useless compds. are progressed. The American Chem. Society (ACS) is eager to alert the scientific community to this problem and to recommend protocols that will eliminate the publication of research articles based on compds. with artificial activity. This editorial aims to summarize relevant concepts and to set the framework by which relevant ACS journals will address this issue going forward.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXjtl2lsLY%253D&md5=64bf087659a47fe7769208217ef8c989

      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Seven Year Itch: Pan-Assay Interference Compounds (PAINS) in 2017-Utility and Limitations
      Baell, Jonathan B.; Nissink, J. Willem M.
      ACS Chemical Biology (2018), 13 (1), 36-44CODEN: ACBCCT; ISSN:1554-8929. (American Chemical Society)
      A review on all necessary considerations for the appropriate use of PAINs filters formulated to process hundreds and thousands of compds. in seconds, and identify PAINS in order to exclude them from further anal.
